children.subject:
Math 54 and EE16A should not be taken. This does not make sense from a learning point of view.

To be clear. The *very strong* recommendation is for EE16A + EE16B. This is what all students going forward should be taking. Advise all your friends to take EE16A and 16B as they enter Berkeley. These are freshman courses intended to be taken by students who have AP-ed out of calculus and taken alongside CS61A and CS61B.  

After that, for students who have already taken Math 54 for some reason and understand the material well, the recommendation is to take Math 54 and EE16B. You will have to study some material extra to be able to do this, and if you really understand the linear algebra in Math 54, this shouldn't be a challenge. If you don't really understand linear algebra, this will be painful. Try your hand at 16A homeworks. If 16A homework is hard for you, you don't really understand linear algebra. 

The least favored choice, and the one that will not be available to future students because it does not make sense, is to take Math 54 and EE16A. The only reason this option is still available is because of grandfathering requirements (it is hard to remove ways of satisfying requirements for students who are already in the program). We do not believe this option serves your educational interests well because the material in EE16B is important for the future. 

EE16B contains treatments of things like the SVD and the like that are critical for machine learning, robotics, and other subparts of CS that we believe are going to be broadly important during students' working careers.

Thank you so much! I really appreciate the detailed response that covered all cases.
Thank you.
I don't get it -- isn't EE16A required for 16B? Math 54 doesn't have any circuits/labs/physics, so why is skipping EE16A recommended for those who already took Math 54?

If you have taken math 54 (and really understood it - to the level of solving all of the 16A linear algebra-related homework problems) but not physics 7B things indeed aren't quite as clear cut, but Anant's recommendation above was based on the idea (that I agree with) that it would be better for your education overall to self-study the ~5-6 weeks of circuits content in 16A to get ready for 16B and then spend a semester actually learning the material in 16B.  The alternative - i.e., taking 16A after having taken 54 (again, assuming you understood it well) - would involve spending a full semester on that 5-6 weeks of content, while about 9-10 weeks would be repeated material (albeit from a different perspective).  

We are working on instituting formal self-paced transition courses that one could take to make up specific sub-pieces of 16A (particularly circuits) to get ready for 16B, and we'll make another announcement once those are ready.  In the mean time, if anyone is in this situation (i.e., has taken 54 and understood it well enough to be able to do the all of the linear algebra problems on the 16A honeworks, but has not taken physics 7B or similar), please feel free to reach out to me so that we can discuss your situation in more detail and I can provide some tailored advice.

I recommend an even better option to take Math 110 + EE 16A. I haven't heard the most positive reviews of EE 16B, it still appears to be in the early stages and it has room to improve. Math 110 is good to take right after EE 16A. Hopefully the dept will exempt students of taking 54 after they take 110. I don't know if this will be the case, because 110 does not cover differential equations.

Will the self-paced version of 16A for circuits material be offered next semester? Or is that not known yet.
(I'm currently planning on taking Math 110 and EE 16A next semester, which would presumably be a weird combo in terms of linear algebra content...)

We're working on getting the self-paced courses (which will be in a format very similar to the CS47 series) approved right now, so I don't know for sure when they will be offered.  It might happen by this Fall, but please stay tuned for a formal announcement on that. 

That said, as I mentioned in one of the follow ups below, I am happy to offer to anyone who is interested to unofficially help with them through the circuits content from 16A to get them ready for 16B.  Please just drop me a line if you are interested in that.

As a final note, there is certainly room for improvement in 16A/B (the classes are still relatively quite new), and we have been looking carefully at all of the feedback we've received in a constant effort to improve.  To speak to 16B specifically, there is a lot of material covered there that is not taught even in math 110, and I strongly believe that material is extremely useful for a wide cross-section of EECS. (To give you a bit of a preview, the final project for 16B involves building a voice controlled robot car.)  So, while Math 110 is certainly a great class (and really doesn't need to "compete" with the other options), at least in my opinion (shared by my colleagues, hence the requirements being what they are), 16B is in general the more widely applicable and appropriate option.

I taken both Math 54 and 16A, and although 2/3  of the classes overlap, I think if students have room to take them, they should  take all 3 classes. 

I personally found both 54 and 16A pretty easy, but even so, I don't think its a waste of time.  EE 16A gives you an EE perspective for the math and also has the circuits module.

I feel like 54 however also gives a much stronger linear algebra foundation, working with matrices, especially once you get to eigenvalues, diagonalization, etc.

Additionally, in the differential equations portion of 54, you spend more time understanding how to solve ODE's and how it looks in matrix form.  Also working with complex numbers and Fourier series.   

It makes the parts of 16B much better, especially the beginning with differential equations and RLC circuits.  Also working in I guess the main reason I think students should take 54, is that 16AB do teach the math, many concepts are rushed through.

I personally would have managed just fine on 16AB, but I feel many students would learn/know the material better with 54. (countering "Math 54 and EE16A should not be taken. This does not make sense from a learning point of view")
^ Math 54 is a great class. I learned so much when I took it. The EE 16A linear algebra seems not as strong imo.

Please feel free to email me with suggestions. We are always working to improve 16AB. Any place where you feel that 16AB rushed through some concept, I really want to know so that can be fixed. 

It is 16A+16B that together hit essentially everything that is in 54 plus a lot more detail. Comparing 54 and 16A is not the right comparison. 

I was struck by one comment: "how ODEs look in matrix form" is what 16B spends a lot of time on. Interpreting eigenvalues and eigenvectors in terms of dynamics, etc... I would really like to understand how you felt that part wasn't covered in as much depth in 16B. 

The motivation behind our recommendations is that 4 years 4 courses per term 2 terms per year is 32 course slots total. We want students to get the most out of them.

The ODE material in 16B was quite rushed and 'hand wavy'. 54 certainly went into more depth and theoretical rigor on ODEs, partly because ODEs were only covered in discussions in 16B (although perhaps the intention of the 16 series was to demonstrate application over theory).

On a separate note, I took 54 in my first semester and towards the end, we were introduced to PDEs and separation of variables, a concept that I had never seen in high school and consequently blew my mind at the time. Again, I do not know how much application this would have in the 16 series (or EE in general for that matter).

Thanks for the input!  Just as small note on this, there was one semester in 16B where the matrix view of ODEs was covered only in discussion, but this material has otherwise been (and will continue to be) explicitly covered in lecture otherwise.
Are there any updates on whether self-paced 16A circuits will be offered in Fall or is it still uncertain? I'm trying to plan my schedule for next semester.
Let me double check on this - I believe the courses are still being officially approved, but they may indeed be offered this Fall.  Will get back to you.
Any update so far on the Self-Paced course? Phase 1 is coming up in few weeks. Thanks!
Between option 2 (Math 54 and EE 16A) and option 3 (Math 54 and EE 16B), which would be more recommended?

The short answer is that in practice, no, 110 does not factor in to this.  To provide a bit more detail, formally, the requirements are exactly as stated in the original post.  Informally, I would personally positively consider a petition to have math 110 and 16B fulfill the requirement (since 110 certainly covers the material from 54), but I don't imagine this is a case of practical interest.  For legacy reasons I would also positively consider math 110 and 16A, but I would highly discourage anyone from taking that path.

To be clear, as Anant mentioned above, 16B covers quite a bit of material that is not covered in either math 54 or math 110, and so from a learning standpoint 16B is really the key requirement.
Will taking Math 110 factor into this in any way?
^don't think physics and ee (lower div at least) are very much related. I wish I could take math and physics instead of ee but they changed it like one semester after I've taken them all

Here is the 111a syllabus for Spr 17. 

http://instrumentationlab.berkeley.edu/FallSyllabus

yes but ee has more than just labs. it also has some "rigorous" linear algebra and nodal/circuit analysis.

ngl I want EE to be way more like physics but it's just different (imo for the worse but thats up to your opinion) so I don't think they'll replace it with any physics soon

Please see my response above regarding 110 for a little more detail.  Briefly though, I would positively consider a petition to use 110 instead of 54 or 16A, although I'm not sure there are many practical cases where that would matter. 16B however does not have any courses that are appropriate replacements, so no, neither Math 110 nor Physics 111A would be acceptable substitutes for that.

Please also see Anant's description above for a little more of the rationale behind all of this, and for a bit more detail about what 16B covers.  The 16 series was structured to emphasize design of efficient systems (in both the linear algebra and circuits/sensors content), and is really the foundation for what almost all of modern EE is about.  The courses are still relatively young and we are constantly making efforts to improve how well we meet this objective, but this basic difference in objective is one of the reasons why there are currently no other courses that would serve as an appropriate replacement.

Is Math 110 an acceptable substitute for 54? 

And, is Math 110 an acceptable substitute for 54 and 16b?

And, is Math 110 and Physics 111A an acceptable substitute for 54 and 16b?

See two follow-ups up regarding Math110.

Math54 + Math110 doesn't cover any EE.
No, this is not an option - please see Anant's and my responses above for more details about why this would not meet the requirement.

Is another possible option:
Math 54 and Math 110?

Please stay tuned for another announcement on this, but the department voted to simply remove the (math 54 or math 110) requirement for EECS majors.  In other words, 16A+16B would be all you need to take (instead of one of the two math courses and 16A/B).  There may be further approvals required before this becomes official however, so please don't take this as formal policy until we've made the announcement.
Definitely keep us posted on that^, I plan to take Math 54/110 next semester otherwise.

What are the plans with the Math 54 requirement in EECS?

Currently, EECS majors have to take 16AB, and they get to choose between 54 and 110. Will the 54 option be removed? Would EE 127 make a good choice for a substitute?

I haven't taken 110 or 127, so I'm not familiar with either. I'm just curious, because I want to understand the roadmap. (I have taken 16AB and 54, so I've fully satisfied the requirements.)

At the current time, unless you are graduating Fall 2017 or earlier, the EE16 requirement cannot be fulfilled by taking an upper division EE class instead.  We are evaluating the amount of backlog need for EE16A/B, and if it looks like there will still be resource issues due to that we will once again consider allowing that on a purely temporary basis.  That is all still highly speculative at this point though, so I'd recommend that you plan for the requirements as stated in the original post.

As I also mentioned in some of the other responses, even if you have taken 54 and 110, you will see a lot of new material in 16B that I believe you'll find very useful for a wide variety of areas within EECS.  So, for many of you, I believe that 16B is really the best option overall.

Unfortunately, I don't think EE16B is a good option for me. While I did very well in Math 54 and 110, I don't think I can do well in 16B so I will definitely take 16A instead. This is because I haven't taken any physics courses for years and the last time I took one (in high school) I did very poorly. Professor Sahai suggested above to go over material of 16A and take 16B instead. But I know pretty much nothing about circuits or... anything really. In this situation, is it realistic for me to learn the material of 16A myself alone and learn more in 16B compared to 16A?

I personally believe this applies to most L&S CS students who do not have a penchant for physics. I personally don't like physics and I'm afraid of taking 16B without 16A. Is this fear irrational?

I don't believe you should be fearful of the content in 16B, or of catching up on the circuits content in 16A.  The emphasis in both courses is really on design (as opposed to analysis, which is more commonly the focus in many intro physics courses), and linear algebra concepts are leveraged quite heavily in the circuits section.  Also, 16A is specifically designed to teach the material to freshman without requiring a specific prior physics background.

I imagine there are indeed many students in the situation you described, and I'd hate to see those of you in that group end up spending a full semester on 5-6 weeks of new material when you could have instead learned what's in 16B (which I honestly believe is really important for everyone).  So, let me make a specific suggestion as well as an offer to help. 

Basically, my suggestion would be very similar to Anant's - i.e., watch the lectures/do the homeworks/midterm problems for the circuits module from 16A, and then go ahead and enroll in 16B the semester after that.  For anyone who wants to take this path (which I obviously realize is more work overall than just taking 16A), I am happy to make myself available (via office hours, email, appointment, etc.) to help with answering questions, clarifying concepts, or general "shepherding" of learning that material.  If anyone is interested in taking me up on this offer, please feel free to send me an email.  (If many people are interested in this, I will potentially start another thread here to make things a little easier to organize.)

As a final note, the circuits module in 16A is just about to start this week, so if you want to shadow along with what's going on there (e.g., watch lecture, come to honework party/office hours, etc.), now is actually a really good time to start.

I'm a TA for EE 16A, and I hold office hours with Professor Stojanovic (the time and location are on the course website: ee16a.com). You're welcome to come to our office hours to ask questions. We prioritize conceptual questions, but questions regarding homework/discussion/past material are still welcome.

Currently, there are very few students that show up, so I'd be happy to help with 16A concepts. Of course, since we're moving into the circuits module, there might be more students showing up to ask questions about the new material.

Actually, I felt that 16a circuit design seemed arbitrary and confusing, and the circuit section took a lot out of the beauty of math and physics with the general methods they used that seemed to bypass it.

On the contrary, EE16b was very enjoyable for me. I was strong in math 110 too and there was a great deal of math involved in the last 2/3 of the class with controls, SVD PCA, sampling, and DFT

As someone very interested by the idea of skipping ahead to EE16B, I want to ask Prof Alon (alongside anyone else) a question; while one can certainly self-learn/shadow the circuits material for 16A, how do you suggest we work to learn the material covered by lab-work in 16A? For perspective, I haven't been in a science lab in years, so I'm slightly concerned my lack of lab experience will punish me in 16B, but I really like the idea of not wasting my time learning the linear algebra covered in 16A again, especially since 54 (and CS 189, now) goes above and beyond said scope.

In terms of "core concepts", the labs in 16A don't generally cover anything beyond what's covered in the lectures; they of course provide further reinforcement of (and motivation/excitement for) the concepts/techniques by giving you practice with them in a practical/application setting, but they don't develop new concepts per se.

The above said, there are some practical skills that you get exposure to in the 16A labs that will be used again in 16B -e.g., using electrical instrumention, breadboarding, soldering, and basic debugging.  Out of these, debugging is by far the most important; the good news however is that the early labs in 16B are designed specifically to develop maturity in exactly these skills - and especially in debugging - since you'll be using those in the final project in 16B.

In terms of specific things you can do, I'll offer a couple of suggestions.  First, there are a number of online courses (like e.g. EE40 on EdX) that you can order the parts/etc for and follow along at your own pace specifically for the labs.  Similarly, all of the lab material for 16A is online, so you can at least take a look at what's happening there to get a feel for it; you can also come talk to the 16A lab staff and they can point you to where you can buy some of the materials/etc. to try things out on your own if you'd like (e.g., in the maker space in Cory). You might also be able to just go to the labs happening in 16A now and see if you can join in with an existing group, but obviously if the lab is full/too many people do this at once it would be problematic.  

As a final note (that certainly isn't finalized yet), because we know that there will likely be a set of people in this exact situation (i.e, not having taken 16A), we may try to put together an extra optional "lab intro" type session in to 16B to help get you familiarized.  As we figure out more about the feasibility of that I will keep you in the loop.  

The summary of all this though is that I do believe you can make up for the lab skills (and learning) from 16A, although really doing the labs obviously takes a bit more effort than just studying the material itself.

I hope this helps - if anyone would like to chat about this more, please feel free to reach out to me.

Is it possible to satisfy EE16A or EE16B requirement with an upperdivision EE course (like EE 126 or 127) for L&S CS majors? I've already taken Math 54 and Math 110. If yes, which upperdiv EE courses would satisfy?

It would probably be a good idea to see how you feel about the Math 54 content closer to the end of the semester (as opposed to now when a lot of the learning is probably still happening), but if at that point you look over the homework problems in 16A (at least the linear algebra related ones) and are having trouble solving them, you might want to take EE16A.  Even in that case, I would still recommend taking EE16B afterwards (both from an overall learning standpoint, as well as because many upper division classes will be adjusting to the assumption that everyone has taken EE16A+B), but if you are a currently enrolled student then that would obviously be up to you (i.e, having taken 16A and Math 54 would be sufficient to fullfil the requirements).
If I'm currently in Math 54, but I do not feel confident about the material, would it be recommended to take EE16A, and then EE16B, or jump straight into EE16B?

I took EE16AB my freshman year, and I completely agree with this. Take EE16AB, spend some time on the material to truly appreciate it, and have your mind blown. The classes focus on intuition instead of just solving some math problems mechanically, and Math 54 doesn't do that (I'm echoing the opinion of literally every person who I've spoken to who took Math 54). Even if you think you don't care about EE, take these classes.

Really? I guess it also depends on the professor and GSI, because I loved Math 54, and I felt it gives a much deeper intuition of mathematics underlying all these EE concepts  (I posted on a followup above). 

I also will admit I thought my GSI was a big part of the positive experience, really challenged our section and went over rigorous proofs, and gave intros to concepts concepts more advanced and really connected everything together.

If you have to pick two, (well EECS already has to), 16AB clearly makes more sense, but I really think Math 54 is very valuable.  It teaches the mechanics of all the computation you need, but also conceptually (IMO).  Its a great complement to the 16 series, even for strong students.

"deriving the golden ratio as the principal eigenvalue of the fibonacci Q-matrix" was well covered in Math 54 when I took it (Fall 2015).

While EE16AB are a better combination in most ways, taking them in their freshmen year for intended L&S CS majors, while trying to declaring and keeping other major options open, isn't viable for everyone. Intended L&S CS majors, opt for Math 54 as it keeps other major options open for them. Hence, I welcome the idea of keeping Math 54 along with EE16A/B, as an option to fulfil linear algebra + EE requirements for L&S CS majors.

For any incoming freshman who are reading this, I would like to strongly re-emphasize Anant's suggestion above that EE16A + EE16B is for the large majority of you the best overall plan.  For incoming freshman, the only two options will be 16A + 16B, or Math 54 + 16B.  The latter option however will require some self-learning of the circuits content from 16A, and while we will be making resources available to help with that (please see the posts/response in this thread), unless you are planning to potentially major in something that specifically requires math 54, there really isn't a benefit to taking that approach.  I'd like to also note that we are in the process of actively reaching out to other departments to make it so that they will accept 16A+16B as an alternative to math 54 (for both prerequisites and majors); if anyone has a specific major/department they'd like to make sure we reach out to on that front, please feel free to contact me.

Just want to add my opinion here. I would also strongly encourage any freshmen reading this to take the EE 16AB combo.

To anyone who doesn't want to take EE classes because they had bad experiences with circuits in high school, please know that EE 16A and B cover a lot more than just the stuff that we think of as stereotypically "EE" (such as circuits). My favourite parts of the course were actually controls and signals, which I didn't even know were a thing before taking the courses. And even the circuits module is taught in a much different way from what most high school students are used to seeing. The rules of how to solve circuits are laid out in a very clear, logical way, and the professors take every opportunity to tie circuits concept back to linear algebra. I wasn't very fond of circuits before taking the series, but taking it changed my mind so much that I'm actually taking an upper-div circuits class right now (EE 105).

Even more importantly, I think the biggest advantage of taking the EE 16AB series is that the stuff you learn is applicable to so many other EECS courses that you will likely take. Just yesterday, I was working on a homework for CS 191 (Quantum Computing), and I was totally lost because I had not been going to lecture. The problem I was working on had something to do with quantum algorithms. I realized that the problem could be solved using the Discrete Fourier Transform, which is one of the big topics in EE 16B. I'm pretty sure that was not the intended way to solve the problem, but my knowledge of 16B material helped me do it anyway! And there are countless other examples of places where EE 16AB material will come in handy, such as the Singular Value Decomposition and Principal Component Analysis in CS 189 and the Fast Fourier Transform algorithm in CS 170, to name a few. Not to mention the fact that 16AB will give you experience working with IPython notebooks, which have been an immensely useful tool for me when doing data-analysis type projects. And lastly, EE 16B has given me a great intuition for linear algebra which I don't think I would have gotten from 54.

To anyone who isn't sure what to take, from a student to another student, I'd really recommend the EE 16A/B combo as professors and other students have previously mentioned. 16A was my first exposure to linear algebra and I really loved the application based perspective the class taught it from. I recall deriving the golden ratio as the principal eigenvalue of the fibonacci Q-matrix and thought that was so cool, something my friends who took 54 (and even one who took H54) said was never covered. Not to mention the labs are so cool - you get to build a touchscreen, GPS, and basic imaging system. It gives you a broad taste of different applications of math/physics/engineering, and it was a nice class to take with 61A which I felt was fairly theoretical, they balanced each other out pretty well.

When I applied to places for undergrad, I applied everywhere as just a CS major, except for here. I'm currently in 16B and the stuff we've learned so far (CMOS logic gates, frequency domain analysis/filters) are honestly some of the most fascinating things I've ever learned in my life and the class has me seriously considering switching my focus to EE, which is not something I ever thought I would say. Highly recommend taking the 16 series, there is so much to learn. Worst case scenario you'll come out with a solid foundation in linear algebra and have a much better idea of what's going on under the hood of your phone/computer :)
which math concepts other than PCA/SVD helped you get your internship?

A lot of the signal processing techniques have broader use cases outsides of actual communication. But in regards to your question, a lot of systems try to implement control feedback loops, and being able to do controls well is an invaluable skill.

I would highly, highly recommend students take 16B in some form or fashion. The higher concepts from 16B are extremely useful in a variety of applications (for example PCA has broad ML applications). I got my first internship in Data Engineering using knowledge from 16B math and analysis.  Even if you have no understanding of hardware, the actual math concepts found in 16B prepare you for many many applications outside of circuits.

One of the key points of the 16 series as a whole is to gain some exposure to how one casts problems/applications of interest in to an appropriate mathematical model (and the tools you can use to manipulate/extract data from those modles), so from that standpoint I think it will still be useful even if you have taken 189.  The exact degree of usefulness to machine learning beyond 189 obviously depends on a lot of individual-specific factors.  In case you happened to be interested in robotics (including things like self-driving cars), 16B does cover a good chunk of material that is directly relevant to that (specifically what's known as "control").
How useful is EE 16B for Machine Learning other than the SVD/PCA part of it? Is it useful for someone who has already taken 189 (I haven't, but just curious) and wants to do machine learning?

In terms of linear algebra specifically, 16A covers just about everything that 54 does, so there isn't too much differentiation there.  (Differential equations aren't covered until 16B however.). This obviously doesn't answer the question of whether it is "enough" for the upper division courses, and the answer to that isn't fully static in that since 16B will be required for both new L&S CS and EECS majors, I expect that many upper division classes will be adjusting to the assumption that their students have taken that class.  For 189 specifically, as discussed above, 16B is very specifically relevant, so I'd recommend taking that first.
In what ways is EE 16B relevant to 189?
A lot of Machine Learning and signal processing use similar concepts, since they're largely about getting meaning results out of noisy data.

16B is targeted very much at building the maturity and conceptual base that 189 requires. I'm scheduled to co-teach189 in the coming fall, so I can say this pretty clearly. Specifically, it is the deeper understanding of the SVD and PCA, as well as the more in-depth view of changes of coordinates that are particularly important. The 16A material on projections and linear least squares is also key. The linearization of nonlinear terms that is covered in the control segment of 16B is also very relevant.

Professor Sahai, if I've taken Math 54 and Math 110 before 189 next semester, will you consider that enough for linear algebra pre-reqs for CS 189? Will EE 16B be a hard pre-req? (I have a very solid understanding of the material taught in Math 54 and 110).
Math 110 should be sufficient for 189. Math 54 on its own probably will not be.

I am taking CS 189 right now, and I certainly think that EE 16AB has given me the linear algebra experience necessary for the course. Even better, 16AB gives you intuition about matrices and vectors, which I don't think 54 gives you. 16A and B together form a year-long course, and they constantly provide opportunities to apply the linear algebra knowledge in labs. So by the end of it, you start being able to manipulate matrix expressions just as easily as you would scalar expressions.

Of course, CS 189 also involves some amount of self-study in linear algebra in order to do the more difficult problems on the homeworks, but I think this would be true regardless of whether I had taken 54/110.
Is the linear algebra is EE16A enough for other upper div CS courses like CS 189?
From reading posts on this thread, it seems that you'll need to do a review of circuits on your own, but otherwise you should be well prepared for EE16B having only taken Math 54.

Also thinking about Applied Mathematics. If I were to skip EE16A and instead take 16B during the summer, would I be missing anything critical besides circuits? I looked at the syllabus and, while the first few weeks seem like Linear Algebra review, the topics not covered by Math 54 seem interesting.

For intended CS Majors also considering applied math, it appears to me that math 54 to EE16B is the more efficient course route, as Applied Math requires Math 54. Otherwise, the student has to take Math 54, EE16A, and EE16B to follow your recommended L and S CS path and fulfill the applied math major requirement. For those who would rather take the 54 to 16B path, will there be a significant gap in understanding by skipping EE16A?

Please see the more detailed response I posted to this query earlier in this thread (the original question was posted on 2-13 I believe), but the short answer is that there are no current plans to allow this; even if that changes, it would be on an exclusively temporary basis.  

Do you have any interest in robotics?  If so, I think you'll find plenty of interesting material in 16B in particular (it sounds like 16A certainly wouldn't be the best choice for you to finish the requirement, at least assuming you've taken math 54 already).  If you'd like to chat more about the details of what's covered and why I personally believe it should be of interest to everyone, please feel free to reach out to me directly.

Is there any possibility in future to replace EE16A with any other EE upper classes such as EE127/227B? I'm planning to graduate Spring 2018 and I think I may have a solid background in linear algebra and machine learning. Berkeley has so many interesting classes that I want to have a try, and thus I hope to take more useful classes for me rather than 16A/B.

history.content:
UPDATE 7/24/17: these requirements have been approved since the original date of this post, for new requirements see this page. Current LSCS referred to here are students who have been admitted prior to Fall 2017.

Effective once L&S executive committee approves (and we don't expect that to take more than 1 or 2 months max), current LSCS students will have some additional options to fulfill the lower division EE and linear algebra requirements.

Students can choose from the following options:

  1. EE 16A and EE 16B (recommended)
  2. Math 54 and EE 16A
  3. Math 54 and EE 16B
history.subject: Change to lower division EE & linear algebra requirements for LSCS

#pin

Students can choose from the following options:

  1. EE 16A and EE 16B (recommended)
  2. Math 54 and EE 16A
  3. Math 54 and EE 16B

#pin
history.subject: Change to lower division EE & linear algebra requirements
